intro: Zaluzianskia ancylopoda, commonly known as the narrow-leaved morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a herbaceous annual with distinctive heart-shaped leaves and trumpet-shaped blue to purple flowers that bloom in the morning. The plant belongs to the Convolvulaceae family, which includes other climbing vines and morning glories. Its flowers are typically 2–4 inches long and have five petals, with a prominent spur at the base. Zaluzianskia ancylopoda thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands, ditches, and along stream banks.
